results.title: Unraveling One of Rock’s Deepest Mysteries: Les Rallizes Dénudés
results.abstract: The Japanese band that emerged in the late 1960s was known for its rumbling rhythms and ear-shredding feedback — but almost nothing was known about its leader, Takashi Mizutani.

multimedia.caption: From left: Mikio Nagata, Takashi Mizutani, Shunichiro Shoda and Takeshi Nakamura of Les Rallizes Dénudés. After decades of intrigue, the band is finally getting the archival treatment.
multimedia.copyright: Akira Uji, via The Last One Musique

multimedia.caption: From left: Mikio Nagata, Takashi Mizutani, Shunichiro Shoda and Takeshi Nakamura of Les Rallizes Dénudés. After decades of intrigue, the band is finally getting the archival treatment.
multimedia.copyright: Akira Uji, via The Last One Musique

multimedia.caption: From left: Mikio Nagata, Takashi Mizutani, Shunichiro Shoda and Takeshi Nakamura of Les Rallizes Dénudés. After decades of intrigue, the band is finally getting the archival treatment.

results.title: Sacheen Littlefeather, Activist Who Rejected Brando’s Oscar, Dies at 75
results.abstract: The actress was booed at the Academy Awards in 1973 after she refused the best actor award on Marlon Brando’s behalf in protest of Hollywood’s depictions of Native Americans.
org_facet: Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences

multimedia.caption: Ms. Littlefeather and Mr. Brando had become friends through her neighbor, the director Francis Ford Coppola.
Ms. Littlefeather and Mr. Brando had become friends through her neighbor, the director Francis Ford Coppola.

results.title: Review: In Stoppard’s ‘Leopoldstadt,’ a Memorial to a Lost World
results.abstract: The Viennese Jewish family at the heart of this new Broadway production thinks it is too assimilated to be in danger when the Nazis arrive. They are wrong.

multimedia.caption: A Passover Seder during Tom Stoppard’s harrowing new play, “Leopoldstadt,” at the Longacre Theater in Manhattan.
A Passover Seder during Tom Stoppard’s harrowing new play, “Leopoldstadt,” at the Longacre Theater in Manhattan.

results.title: ‘Bros’ Fails at the Box Office, as ‘Smile’ Arrives at No. 1
results.abstract: Promoted as the first gay romantic comedy from a major studio, “Bros” sold $4.8 million in tickets, about 40 percent less than expected.

multimedia.caption: Luke Macfarlane and Billy Eichner in “Bros,” which was embraced by critics but arrived in fourth place at the box office.
Luke Macfarlane and Billy Eichner in “Bros,” which was embraced by critics but arrived in fourth place at the box office.
Luke Macfarlane and Billy Eichner in “Bros,” which was embraced by critics but arrived in fourth place at the box office.

results.title: Billy Eichner Wrote Himself Into the Romance He Wanted With ‘Bros’
results.abstract: In the film, he channels his relationship angst into something hopeful: “I was like, ‘Why is the fictional version of me happier than I am?’”

multimedia.caption: “Until very recently, if Hollywood was willing to put a gay character in anything, it was often to be some version of a live-action cartoon,” Billy Eichner said.
multimedia.copyright: Ryan Pfluger for The New York Times

results.title: White House Restores Arts Commission Dissolved Under Trump
results.abstract: The move rolls back the outcome of one of the stormier episodes in the former president’s mutually antagonistic relationship with artists and cultural figures.

results.title: Museums Vote to Allow the Sale of Art to Care for Collections

results.title: Joe Bussard, Obsessive Collector of Rare Records, Dies at 86
results.abstract: His life revolved around his massive hoard of fragile 78 r.p.m. disks of jazz, blues, country and gospel music recorded between the 1920s and ’50s.

multimedia.caption: Joe Bussard in 2009 with his collection of rare 78 r.p.m. records in the basement of his home in Maryland. He would go door to door hunting them down.
